docs.abstract: The decision by Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the district attorney since 2010, sets off a scramble for the office and makes it likely a new prosecutor will inherit an investigation into the former president’s business.
docs.snippet: The decision by Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the district attorney since 2010, sets off a scramble for the office and makes it likely a new prosecutor will inherit an investigation into the former president’s business.
docs.lead_paragraph: Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the Manhattan district attorney, announced on Friday he would not run for re-election, setting off a wide-open race to lead one of the most important crime-fighting offices in the country and making it highly likely that any potential case against President Donald J. Trump will be left in a newcomer’s hands.

headline.main: New Adversary Looms for Trump as Vance Exits Manhattan D.A. Race
headline.print_headline: New Adversary Looms for Trump as Manhattan D.A. Confirms He Won’t Run Again

docs.abstract: New York is finally giving its Police Department the scrutiny it deserves.
docs.snippet: New York is finally giving its Police Department the scrutiny it deserves.
docs.lead_paragraph: In New York, a 1-year-old boy was fatally shot over the weekend, one of the latest victims in a surge of violence that has rattled an already traumatized city. As of Monday, New York City had had 634 shootings this year, up from 394 at the same time last year, according to Police Department data.

headline.main: The N.Y.P.D. Has Rejected Reform for Decades. It Can’t Anymore.

docs.abstract: The revelation provoked gasps at the disciplinary hearing for the officer who applied a chokehold to Mr. Garner, who died after exclaiming, “I can’t breathe.”
docs.snippet: The revelation provoked gasps at the disciplinary hearing for the officer who applied a chokehold to Mr. Garner, who died after exclaiming, “I can’t breathe.”
docs.lead_paragraph: [What you need to know to start the day: Get New York Today in your inbox.]

headline.main: Eric Garner Death Was ‘Not a Big Deal,’ Police Commander Said
headline.print_headline: Garner Death  Not ‘Big Deal’  To Lieutenant

docs.abstract: The phrase the president tweeted, “When the looting starts, the shooting starts,” was used by a Miami police chief widely condemned by civil rights groups.
docs.snippet: The phrase the president tweeted, “When the looting starts, the shooting starts,” was used by a Miami police chief widely condemned by civil rights groups.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An incendiary phrase used by President Trump in a tweet about the protests over George Floyd’s death in Minneapolis appears to have originated in a 1967 news conference held by a Miami police chief long accused of using racist tactics in his force’s patrols of black neighborhoods.

headline.main: ‘Looting’ Comment From Trump Dates Back to Racial Unrest of the 1960s
headline.print_headline: Trump’s Remark Traces Roots to a Police Chief Accused of Racist Tactics

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: National Assn for the Advancement of Colored People

docs.abstract: The department also announced limits on federal officers’ use of widely criticized policing tactics.
docs.snippet: The department also announced limits on federal officers’ use of widely criticized policing tactics.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has opened an investigation into allegations of unconstitutional abuses of prisoners in Georgia, a sweeping civil rights inquiry that could force the state to carry out a federally mandated overhaul.

headline.main: Justice Dept. to Investigate Georgia Prisons
headline.print_headline: Georgia Prisons Investigated Over Abuse Allegations

docs.abstract: The collapse of politics and governance leaves no other option.
docs.snippet: The collapse of politics and governance leaves no other option.
docs.lead_paragraph: Ready or not, life is returning to some sort of normal in the United States, and normal inevitably includes police officers killing an unarmed black man in their custody, followed by street protests. The country is working its way back into its familiar groove.

headline.main: Of Course There Are Protests. The State Is Failing Black People.

docs.abstract: Understanding diversity in the suburbs is a key to winning elections.
docs.snippet: Understanding diversity in the suburbs is a key to winning elections.
docs.lead_paragraph: The suburban school is an imagined space that invites an unhealthy amount of hyperbole, misinterpretation and fear. All-white classrooms with a few token Asians, expansive, well-kept playing fields and pickup circles filled with Volvo S.U.V.s driven by anxious, potentially reactionary mothers might still exist in small pockets of the country. But even many of those privileged spaces have likely seen significant demographic change over the past few decades.

headline.main: Everything You Think You Know About the Suburbs Is Wrong

docs.abstract: For progressives, he's a nightmare. For the rest of big-city America,  he’s a godsend.
docs.snippet: For progressives, he's a nightmare. For the rest of big-city America,  he’s a godsend.
docs.lead_paragraph: Eric Adams arrives for lunch alone, no entourage or media handler. He shows me his new earring — “the first thing,” he says, that Joe Biden “asked to see” when the two met recently to discuss gun violence. He orders a tomato salad with oil on the side, the abstemious diet of the all-but-crowned king of New York.

headline.main: Eric Adams Is Going to Save New York
headline.print_headline: Eric Adams Is Going to Save New York

docs.lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw Alex Eaton-Salners, he was trying to send us a message in Morse code. In this puzzle, nothing is definite unless you count the shaded squares.

docs.abstract: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
docs.snippet: Teenage comments in response to our recent writing prompts, and an invitation to join the ongoing conversation.
docs.lead_paragraph: Happy 2020 to all our students and teachers! To kick off the New Year, we invited students to tell us their predictions about the year and decade ahead. We also asked them what bygone era they would have liked to have grown up in and how they deal with frenzied thoughts.

headline.main: What Students Are Saying About 2020, Growing Up in Another Era, and Distraction
